hypotheses.title: Supply Chain Compromise via Malicious NPM/PyPI Packages Mimicking Legitimate AI/MCP Tools
hypotheses.description: Threat actors, particularly Lazarus Group and SmartLoader, have been actively distributing malicious npm and PyPI packages that impersonate legitimate AI tools (e.g., Oura MCP server) and developer frameworks (e.g., Next.js, Claude artifacts) to deploy StealC infostealers, LummaStealer, and other malware. These campaigns exploit developer trust in open-source ecosystems and AI-assisted tooling.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1574.009 - Hijack Execution Flow: Dynamic-link Library Hijacking
T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution logs (especially npm, pip, node, python), file creation/modification events in project directories, network connections to package registries
tools: EDR (e.g., CrowdStrike, SentinelOne), Sysmon, npm/pip audit logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS queries to registry.npmjs.org, pypi.org, and suspicious subdomains; TLS certificate details for package downloads
tools: Network detection (e.g., Darktrace, Zeek), DNS logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Developer account activity in GitHub, GitLab, npm, PyPI (e.g., new package uploads, compromised publish tokens)
tools: SIEM with identity integration (e.g., Microsoft Sentinel, Splunk UBA)

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Detect Typosquatting and Fake MCP Server Packages
hunting_tactics.description: Search for npm/PyPI packages with names similar to known AI/MCP tools (e.g., 'ouramcp', 'claude-code-security', 'nextjs-interview-test') and verify package metadata and author history.
sample_queries: index=npm_audit OR index=pypi_audit (package_name=*ouramcp* OR package_name=*claude* OR package_name=*nextjs* OR package_name=*interview*) | stats count by package_name, package_version, author, upload_date, dependencies | where upload_date > relative_time(now()-14d)

index=github_audit (action=publish OR action=push) (actor=*lazarus* OR actor=*smartloader* OR repo_name=*nextjs* OR repo_name=*claude* OR repo_name=*ouramcp*) | table actor, repo_name, action, timestamp
hunting_tactics.look_for: Packages with recent upload dates, no GitHub repo link, suspicious dependencies (e.g., 'axios', 'node-fetch'), authors with no prior history, or cloned-looking READMEs with fake forks/contributors

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Detect Malicious Claude Artifacts and MCP Servers
hunting_tactics.description: Hunt for execution of unauthorized Claude artifacts, MCP server processes, or configuration files that attempt to load remote code or exfiltrate credentials.
sample_queries: index=endpoint (process_name=*node* OR process_name=*python* OR process_name=*claude*) (command_line=*mcp* OR command_line=*artifact* OR command_line=*claude* OR file_path=*\.claude* OR file_path=*\.claude* OR file_path=*mcp*) | stats count by process_name, command_line, file_path, host | where count > 1

index=network dest_port=443 (user_agent=*Claude* OR user_agent=*MCP*) (dest_domain=*pastebin* OR dest_domain=*raw.githubusercontent* OR dest_domain=*githubusercontent*) | stats count by src_ip, dest_domain, dest_port, user_agent
hunting_tactics.look_for: Processes spawning from node/python executing MCP server scripts, connections to raw GitHub URLs for config files, suspicious environment variables (e.g., MCP_SERVER_URL, CLAUDE_API_KEY)

network_patterns: DNS queries to newly registered domains with 'mcp', 'claude', 'interview' in name
other_indicators: Fake GitHub forks/contributors in package READMEs
Packages with no test files or minimal code
Use of Pastebin/Gist for second-stage payloads

recommended_actions: Revoke and rotate all npm/PyPI publish tokens if compromise suspected
Block outbound connections to newly registered domains with AI/MCP-related keywords
Audit developer accounts for unauthorized package uploads
Deploy EDR rules to detect execution of scripts from /tmp, /var/tmp, or user-writable directories

hypotheses.title: Exploitation of Unpatched BeyondTrust CVE-2026-1731 Leading to Lateral Movement and Ransomware Deployment
hypotheses.description: BeyondTrust CVE-2026-1731 (CVSS 9.9) has been actively exploited since at least February 2026, with attackers achieving unauthenticated RCE within hours of PoC release. Exploitation has been linked to ransomware deployments (e.g., Medusa, Everest) and deployment of VShell for persistence and lateral movement. The vulnerability affects BeyondTrust Remote Support (RS) and older Privileged Remote Access (PRA) products.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1212 - Credential Stealing via Password Filter DLL

data_sources_needed.specific_data: HTTP/HTTPS traffic to BeyondTrust management interfaces (ports 443, 8080), anomalous POST requests with large payloads, authentication bypass attempts
tools: Firewall logs, IDS/IPS (e.g., Suricata), Zeek HTTP logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process creation logs for vshell.exe, sshd.exe, or unusual child processes of BeyondTrust services, registry modifications under HKLM\SOFTWARE\BeyondTrust
tools: Sysmon, EDR (e.g., CrowdStrike), Windows Event Logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Privileged session logs, failed login attempts to BeyondTrust admin console, new user accounts created via RCE

hunting_tactics.description: Search for HTTP requests to BeyondTrust endpoints containing suspicious parameters or large base64-encoded payloads that could indicate command injection.
sample_queries: index=network (dest_port=443 OR dest_port=8080) (dest_host=*beyondtrust* OR dest_host=*rs.beyondtrust*) (method=POST) (uri=*api* OR uri=*admin* OR uri=*auth*) | regex _raw="(command|exec|eval|base64|/bin/sh|/bin/bash|cmd\.exe)" | stats count by src_ip, dest_host, uri, method | sort -count

index=sysmon EventCode=3 (dest_port=443 OR dest_port=8080) (dest_host=*beyondtrust*) | eval payload=base64_decode(base64_field) | where match(payload, "(command|exec|eval|/bin/sh)") | table src_ip, dest_host, payload
hunting_tactics.look_for: Unusual POST requests to /api/auth, /admin/config, or /rs endpoints with base64-encoded payloads or shell commands, especially from non-standard source IPs

hunting_tactics.description: Look for deployment of VShell (BeyondTrust's SSH server) or other SSH daemons as persistence mechanisms, often alongside new user accounts or scheduled tasks.
sample_queries: index=sysmon EventCode=1 (parent_image=*vshell* OR image=*vshell* OR image=*sshd*) | stats count by parent_image, image, user, host | where count > 0
index=security EventCode=4720 (user_name=*vshell* OR user_name=*ssh*) OR index=security EventCode=4688 (command_line=*vshell* OR command_line=*sshd*) | stats count by user, host, command_line
hunting_tactics.look_for: New user accounts with SSH capabilities, scheduled tasks named 'VShell' or 'SSH', processes spawned from BeyondTrust service accounts executing non-standard binaries

network_patterns: HTTPS to port 443/8080 with POST /api/auth/bypass or POST /admin/config
SSH connections from non-standard IPs to internal hosts
other_indicators: Unusual outbound SSH connections from management servers
New admin accounts created outside business hours
Log entries showing 'unauthenticated access' in BeyondTrust logs

recommended_actions: Immediately patch BeyondTrust RS/PRA to latest version
Block external access to BeyondTrust management interfaces
Audit all privileged accounts created in the last 30 days
Hunt for VShell processes and SSH backdoors on all systems

hypotheses.title: AI-Assisted Credential Theft via Fake Claude Code and GitHub Copilot Exploits
hypotheses.description: Multiple vulnerabilities in Anthropic's Claude Code (CVE-2025-59536, CVE-2026-21852) and GitHub Copilot (RoguePilot) have been actively exploited to enable remote code execution and API key theft when developers clone untrusted repositories. Attackers abuse Hooks, MCP servers, and environment variables to execute arbitrary commands and exfiltrate credentials, often via GitHub Issues or Codespaces.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials in Files
T1195.003 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Developer Tools
T1059.007 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: JavaScript

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution logs for code editors (VS Code, Cursor), Claude Code, GitHub Copilot, and npm scripts; file creation in .claude, .copilot, .github directories
tools: Sysmon, EDR, VS Code extension logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: GitHub Actions workflow runs, Codespace launches, repository clone events, webhook triggers
tools: GitHub Audit Logs, Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS queries to webhook domains, API calls to Anthropic/GitHub endpoints, exfiltration to suspicious domains

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Detect Malicious Claude Code Hooks and MCP Servers
hunting_tactics.description: Search for execution of unauthorized MCP servers or Claude Code hooks that attempt to run shell commands or access environment variables.
sample_queries: index=sysmon EventCode=1 (parent_image=*node* OR parent_image=*python*) (command_line=*mcp* OR command_line=*claude* OR command_line=*hook*) | stats count by parent_image, command_line, host | where count > 0
index=endpoint (file_path=*\.claude* OR file_path=*\.copilot*) (file_name=*config* OR file_name=*hook* OR file_name=*server*) | stats count by file_path, host | where count > 0
hunting_tactics.look_for: Processes spawned from node/python executing MCP server scripts, files in .claude or .copilot directories with .json/.js/.yaml extensions, environment variables containing 'MCP_SERVER_URL' or 'CLAUDE_API_KEY'

hunting_tactics.description: Hunt for GitHub Issues containing hidden instructions that trigger Copilot to execute malicious code in Codespaces.
sample_queries: index=github_audit (action=issue_comment OR action=issue) (body=*copilot* OR body=*claude* OR body=*codespace*) | regex _raw="(exec|eval|run|bash|sh|powershell)" | stats count by actor, repo_name, issue_number, body | sort -count

index=network (user_agent=*GitHub-Copilot*) (dest_domain=*githubusercontent* OR dest_domain=*raw.githubusercontent*) | eval body=base64_decode(base64_field) | where match(body, "(exec|eval|bash)") | stats count by src_ip, dest_domain
hunting_tactics.look_for: GitHub Issues with base64-encoded or obfuscated shell commands, suspicious Copilot instructions in issue descriptions, Codespace launches triggered by issue comments

network_patterns: HTTPS to webhook.site or similar with POST /webhook
DNS queries to newly registered domains with 'mcp', 'claude', 'copilot' in name
other_indicators: GitHub Issues with hidden HTML comments or base64 payloads
Codespace launches triggered by issue comments

recommended_actions: Disable GitHub Copilot in Codespaces for untrusted repositories
Audit Claude Code extensions and hooks for unauthorized code execution
Block outbound connections to webhook domains and newly registered AI-related domains
Review developer environment variables for suspicious API keys

hypotheses.title: Physical and Remote ATM Jackpotting Attacks Using Ploutus Malware
hypotheses.description: The FBI has confirmed a surge in ATM jackpotting attacks, with over $20 million lost in 2025 and 700 incidents reported that year. Attackers exploit physical access to ATMs and deploy malware like Ploutus to manipulate firmware and force cash dispensing. This is often preceded by compromise of ATM management software or internal networks.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1021.003 - Remote Services: Windows Remote Management
T1562.003 - Impair Defenses: Disable Windows Event Logging

data_sources_needed.specific_data: ATM-to-branch network traffic, unusual outbound connections from ATMs, SMB traffic to ATMs (port 445)
tools: Network detection (e.g., Darktrace), ATM firewall logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: ATM process execution logs (e.g., kiosk processes, Windows services), USB device insertion events, disk write activity
tools: EDR for ATMs (e.g., ESET Banker), Windows Event Logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: ATM access logs, surveillance footage, tamper detection events
tools: Physical access control systems, ATM vendor logs

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Detect Ploutus Malware Execution on ATMs
hunting_tactics.description: Search for known Ploutus indicators such as unusual processes, registry keys, or network connections associated with ATM jackpotting.
sample_queries: index=sysmon EventCode=1 (image=*ploutus* OR image=*atm* OR image=*kiosk*) (parent_image=*winlogon* OR parent_image=*explorer*) | stats count by image, parent_image, host | where count > 0
index=endpoint (file_path=*C:\Windows\Temp\*ploutus* OR file_path=*C:\ProgramData\*ploutus*) | stats count by file_path, host | where count > 0
hunting_tactics.look_for: Processes named ploutus.exe, atm.exe, or kiosk.exe running as SYSTEM, registry keys under HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\Ploutus, USB device insertion events followed by disk write activity

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Detect Internal Network Compromise Prior to ATM Attack
hunting_tactics.description: Hunt for lateral movement from compromised branch networks to ATM management systems, often involving SMB or RDP.
sample_queries: index=security EventCode=4624 (logon_type=3) (src_ip=*10.* OR src_ip=*192.168.*) (dest_host=*atm* OR dest_host=*branch*) | stats count by src_user, src_ip, dest_host | where count > 5
index=network (src_ip=*10.* OR src_ip=*192.168.*) (dest_port=445 OR dest_port=3389) (dest_host=*atm*) | stats count by src_ip, dest_host, dest_port | where count > 10
hunting_tactics.look_for: Multiple logons to ATMs from internal IPs, SMB traffic to ATMs from non-standard sources, RDP sessions to ATMs outside business hours

network_patterns: SMB to port 445 from internal IPs to ATMs
DNS queries to C2 domains with 'atm' or 'jackpot' in name
Unusual outbound connections from ATMs to external IPs
other_indicators: USB device insertion events on ATMs
Disk write activity to ATM boot sectors

recommended_actions: Isolate ATMs from branch networks and implement network segmentation
Deploy EDR with ATM-specific detection rules
Audit physical access controls and surveillance for ATMs
Hunt for lateral movement from branch networks to ATM management systems

hypotheses.title: ClickFix Social Engineering Attacks Abusing DNS Tunneling (nslookup) to Deliver Malware
hypotheses.description: The ClickFix campaign has evolved to abuse DNS tunneling via nslookup commands to deliver second-stage payloads, bypassing traditional security controls. Attackers trick users into running malicious nslookup commands that parse DNS responses to retrieve malware, often via fake CAPTCHA or error messages.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution logs for nslookup, cmd.exe, powershell.exe, mshta.exe, and malicious scripts
DNS queries with unusually long subdomains, DNS TXT record queries, nslookup command-line arguments
tools: DNS logs (e.g., Cisco Umbrella, Infoblox), Zeek DNS logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Phishing emails with fake CAPTCHA instructions, malicious attachments, or links to malicious sites

hunting_tactics.description: Search for nslookup commands with suspicious arguments or DNS queries with long, base64-encoded subdomains that may indicate data exfiltration or payload delivery.
sample_queries: index=sysmon EventCode=1 (parent_image=*cmd* OR parent_image=*powershell*) (image=*nslookup*) (command_line=*.*.*.* OR command_line=*txt*) | stats count by parent_image, command_line, host | where count > 0

index=dns (query=*.*.*.* OR query=*txt*) (query_length>50) | eval subdomain=split(query, "\.") | eval payload=mvindex(subdomain, 0) | where len(payload) > 40 | stats count by query, src_ip | sort -count
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup commands with arguments containing base64-encoded strings, DNS TXT queries with unusually long responses, parent processes like cmd.exe or powershell.exe spawning nslookup

hunting_tactics.description: Hunt for phishing emails or web pages with fake CAPTCHA, error messages, or coding challenges that instruct users to run nslookup commands.
sample_queries: index=security (event_type=phishing OR event_type=malicious_url) (body=*nslookup* OR body=*copy.*paste* OR body=*run.*command*) | stats count by src_ip, dest_url, subject | sort -count
index=web (url=*clickfix* OR url=*capcha* OR url=*update.*now*) (user_agent=*Mozilla*) | stats count by url, user_agent, src_ip | where count > 0
hunting_tactics.look_for: Phishing emails with instructions to run nslookup, URLs containing 'clickfix', 'capcha', or 'update now', web pages with fake CAPTCHA that display nslookup commands

network_patterns: DNS TXT queries to domains with long subdomains
HTTP POST requests to clickfix domains with base64 payloads
DNS queries to newly registered domains with 'clickfix', 'capcha', or 'update' in name
other_indicators: Fake CAPTCHA pages with nslookup instructions
Malicious PowerShell scripts encoded in base64

recommended_actions: Block nslookup.exe from running with non-standard arguments
Monitor DNS queries for unusually long subdomains
Deploy email filtering rules to detect ClickFix-themed phishing
Educate developers and IT staff about ClickFix social engineering tactics

unique_mitre_techniques: T1021.003 - Remote Services: Windows Remote Management
T1059.007 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: JavaScript
T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1195.003 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Developer Tools
T1562.003 - Impair Defenses: Disable Windows Event Logging
T1574.009 - Hijack Execution Flow: Dynamic-link Library Hijacking
T1212 - Credential Stealing via Password Filter DLL
T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials in Files
